name: Grasé, Jan Carl Gijsbert aan Verwey, Albert | 1884-02-10

Transcription.text:
¶Wellington House.
Eton Rd NW.
Febr 10th 84

Dear, dear, So you had to write to me at last, or rather you had to ask me at last why I did not write to you before? I shall not try to offer any excuses; but simply state that I am second master now at this place and consequently have a lot of work hanging on my hands which often prevented me from writing to you for days running. This is of course one of the main changes I am subject too, since my departure from London in July of last year.
    ¶I am expected to feel flattered & happy; for having this place offered to me by the headmaster; & as a dutiful citizen, I am both flattered & pleased. Still the work hangs rather heavily upon my hands; I am responsible for every blooming thing in the house.
    How is the Club getting on? and yr debates on politics, art, science political economy, etc. The clergyman in church preached this morning on the beautiful parable of that gentleman, who hired some labourers for his vineyard at different periods of the day & gave them 1d each. ¶He referred to socialism; Some of his remarks were awfully good. God is the capital & man the labour. He afterwards said. The Capital is God. that is all I remember. I went asleep afterwards. & only woke up when they began to sing Lord have mercy upon us & incline our hearts, etc. for the 8th or 9th time. Do you go any more to the English Episcopal Church?
    I go to the blessed place twice every Sunday & meditate during the Sermon & sometimes during the whole service.
    I invent new systems of Philosophy & put above [man's] greatest happiness ¶in the absence of prayer books & presence of roast beef, ale & plum pudding. By Jove. Dutch meat does not agree with me, nor does English church air. Fancy twice a day in the same place, the same vicar, talking a lot of bosh.
    Notepaper will reach yr place shortly I expect, I have forwarded it to Lamsvelt.
    Tea time! [Woe?] [xxxx].

Believe me
Yrs truly
In hell & death
G. Grasé.
